#define DB_CURSOR_TYPE_STATIC   0x00002000u

Update Flags
#define DB_UPDATE_SEEK_NEW   1u
 Move the cursor position to the new position of the current record, if the record's position has changed after the update. More...
 
#define DB_UPDATE_SEEK_NEXT   2u
 Move the cursor position to the next record, based on the position of the record before the update. More...
 
#define DB_UPDATE_SEEK_PRIOR   3u
 Move the cursor position to the previous record, based on the position of the record before the update. More...
 
#define DB_UPDATE_SEEK_MASK   0x07

 Open database for reading only. More...

#define DB_NOLOCKING   0x0004u
 Disable locking. More...
 
#define DB_UTF8_NAME   0x0008u
 File name is in UTF-8 encoding, default is ANSI encoding. More...
 
#define DB_ATOMIC_WRITE   0x0010u
 Write database pages atomically, even if the storage media does not support atomic writes. More...
 
#define DB_CONN_LOCK   0x0020u
 Wait for connection lock instead of try lock.
 
#define DB_RISK_INCONSISTENCY   0x0040u
 Open database even if a required log file is missing. More...
 
#define DB_SNAPSHOT_STORAGE   0x0080u
 Use new snapshot file format. More...

 Verify checksums when data is read from the database file. More...

Data Binding
#define DB_ARRAY_DIM(x)   (sizeof(x) / sizeof(x[0]))
 Get the dimension of a static array. More...
 
#define DB_BIND_STRUCT_MEMBER(field_no, type, bind_struct, member)   { field_no, type, DB_BIND_OFFSET(bind_struct, member), DB_BIND_SIZE(bind_struct, member), -1, DB_BIND_RELATIVE }
 Bind to the offset of a member variable within a struct. More...
 
#define DB_BIND_VAR(field_no, type, var)   { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(&var), sizeof(var), DB_BIND_ADDRESS(NULL), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }
 Bind to the address of a non-pointer data type. More...
 
#define DB_BIND_STR(field_no, type, var)   { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(var), sizeof(var), DB_BIND_ADDRESS(NULL), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }
 Bind to the address of a statically allocated array or string. More...
 
#define DB_BIND_PTR(field_no, type, var, size)   { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(var), size, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(NULL), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }
 Bind to a dynamically allocated pointer with a specified size in bytes. More...
 
#define DB_BIND_STRUCT_MEMBER_IND(field_no, type, bind_struct, value, ind)   { field_no, type, DB_BIND_OFFSET(bind_struct, value), DB_BIND_SIZE(bind_struct, value), DB_BIND_OFFSET(bind_struct, ind), DB_BIND_RELATIVE }
 Bind to the offset of a member variable and its length indicator within a struct. More...
 
#define DB_BIND_VAR_IND(field_no, type, var, ind)   { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(&var), sizeof(var), DB_BIND_ADDRESS(ind), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }
 Bind to the address of a non-pointer data type and its length indicator. More...
 
#define DB_BIND_STR_IND(field_no, type, var, ind)   { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(var), sizeof(var), DB_BIND_ADDRESS(ind), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }
 Bind to the address of a statically allocated array or string and its length indicator. More...
 
#define DB_BIND_PTR_IND(field_no, type, var, size, ind)   { field_no, type, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(var), size, DB_BIND_ADDRESS(ind), DB_BIND_ABSOLUTE }

Variables

 db_server_config_t
 

Detailed Description

Entry point for the ITTIA DB C API.

The C API provides a low-level interface to the database kernel. To access the C API, include ittia/db.h.

#include <ittia/db.h>
db.h
Entry point for the ITTIA DB C API.

Macro Definition Documentation

◆ DB_MEMFLAGS_TRACE

#define DB_MEMFLAGS_TRACE   1

Enable memory allocation statistics.

This incurs additional overhead and should only be used during testing.

See also
db_mem_statistics, db_done_ex.

◆ DB_LOCK_SHARED

#define DB_LOCK_SHARED   0x00000001u

◆ DB_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE

#define DB_LOCK_EXCLUSIVE   0x00000002u

◆ DB_TRY_LOCK

#define DB_TRY_LOCK   0x00010000u

◆ DB_COMMIT_LOCK

#define DB_COMMIT_LOCK   0x00060000u

Release lock automatically when transaction is finished.

◆ DB_INSTANT_LOCK

#define DB_INSTANT_LOCK   0x00020000u

Release lock manually before the transaction is finished.

◆ DB_MEM_TIGHT

#define DB_MEM_TIGHT   1

Use minimal amount of memory possible.

◆ DB_MEM_COMPACT

#define DB_MEM_COMPACT   2

Use a small amount of memory (several times the minimum).

◆ DB_MEM_LARGE

#define DB_MEM_LARGE   3

Use a large amount of memory (several orders of magnitude larger than the minimum).

◆ DB_SINGLE_PROCESS

#define DB_SINGLE_PROCESS   1

Only allow concurrent connections from a single process.

◆ DB_DUPLICATE_SAME_FLAGS

#define DB_DUPLICATE_SAME_FLAGS   (-1)

Use the original flags when a cursor is duplicated.

See also
db_duplicate_cursor

◆ DB_INTERNAL_JOURNAL

#define DB_INTERNAL_JOURNAL   0x0001u

Journal and data are stored in a single file.

◆ DB_EXTERNAL_JOURNAL

#define DB_EXTERNAL_JOURNAL   0x0002u

Journal is stored in a separate file.

◆ DB_NULL_JOURNAL

#define DB_NULL_JOURNAL   0x0003u

Journal is not stored, but transactions are still atomic.

◆ DB_DUMMY_JOURNAL

#define DB_DUMMY_JOURNAL   0x0004u

Use non-atomic transactions.

Tables and indexes may become inconsistent when an error occurs while the dummy journal is used.

◆ DB_SOFT_SHUTDOWN

#define DB_SOFT_SHUTDOWN   0

Perform a soft shutdown, waiting for all transactions to complete.

◆ DB_DESCRIBE_TABLE_FIELDS

#define DB_DESCRIBE_TABLE_FIELDS   0x00001u

Obtain information about fields.

◆ DB_DESCRIBE_TABLE_INDEXES

◆ DB_WATCH_ROW_INSERT

◆ DB_WATCH_MODIFIED_FIELDS

◆ DB_WATCH_ALL_FIELDS

◆ DB_WATCH_FORMER_VALUES

#define DB_WATCH_FORMER_VALUES   0x00008u

◆ DB_WATCH_FILTER_NOT_SELF

#define DB_WATCH_FILTER_NOT_SELF   0x20000u

◆ db_prepare_sql_cursor()

db_cursor_t db_prepare_sql_cursor ( db_t  hdb,
const char *  sql_text,
db_flags_t  flags 
)

Obtain a cursor to access the data from an SQL statement.

Note
db_prepare_sql_cursor requires ITTIA DB-SQL and is not available in ITTIA DB-Standard.
Parameters
hdbDatabase handle.
sql_textSQL query or command.
flagsA bitwise combination of:
  • DB_SCAN_FORWARD
  • DB_SCAN_BACKWARD
  • DB_CURSOR_TYPE_EXCL

And up to one requested cursor type:

  • DB_CURSOR_TYPE_FORWARD (default)
  • DB_CURSOR_TYPE_STATIC
  • DB_CURSOR_TYPE_DYNAMIC

And up to one cursor encoding:

  • DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_ANSI (default)
  • DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF8
  • DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF16
  • DB_CURSOR_ENCODING_UTF32
Returns
  • Cursor handle.
  • NULL on failure.
Note
When no longer needed, the cursor must be closed with db_close_cursor.

All SQL queries support forward-only and static type cursors. Some queries also support dynamic type cursors. If a dynamic cursor is requested that cannot be fulfilled by the query, it is automatically changed to a static cursor unless DB_CURSOR_TYPE_EXCL is also used.

For a given query string, forward-only cursors have the lowest overhead and static cursors the highest. However, some queries always have the same overhead regardless of the cursor type.

The query string, sql_text, must use the encoding specified in the flags, or ANSI encoding by default, and must be NUL-terminated. Literals in the query string must use the same encoding, except for NLS literals of the form N 'value', which always use a Unicode encoding.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: invalid database handle, SQL query parameter is null, invalid flags value.
  • DB_ESTATE Object state is not compatible with the method called or arguments. This could be caused by invalid transaction state.
  • DB_ESQLTABLENOTEXISTS A referenced table does not exist.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDCOLUMNNAME A referenced column does not exist.
  • DB_ESQLCOLUMNAMBIGUOUSLYDEFINED A referenced column is not specifically defined.
  • DB_ESQLINCOMPATIBLETYPES Incompatible types between two or more variables.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDFUNCTIONNAME Unrecognized function used in SQL statement.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDNUMBEROFARGUMENTS Invalid number of arguments used in SQL function call.
  • DB_ESQLININVALIDARGUMENTTYPE Invalid argument type used in SQL function call.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDQUALIFIER Invalid SQL qualifier used in SQL statement.
  • DB_ESQLINCOMPATIBLEROWTYPES Incompatible row types used in SQL statement.
  • DB_ESQLPARSEERROR SQL parsing error. Refer to SQL syntax documentation.
  • DB_ESQLNOTAGROUPBYEXPRESSION Invalid Group-By expression in SQL statement.
  • DB_ESQLFEATURENOTALLOWED Invalid feature reference.
  • DB_ESQLDIVIDEBYZERO SQL Statement results in divide-by-zero.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDRELATIONALOPERATOR Invalid table relation specified.
  • DB_ESQLNOTSORTABLETYPE Sort specified for unsortable data type.

This function does not start or require a transaction, but can be used safely within a transaction.

See also
db_close_cursor
db_get_error_message, get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_execute()

db_result_t db_execute ( db_cursor_t  hcursor,
db_row_t  param_row,
db_object_t  param_object 
)

Performs previously prepared SQL cursor query.

Parameters
hcursorCursor handle.
param_rowPlaceholders in the query are replaced by the values in param_row. Use NULL if the query does not contain placeholders.
param_objectRow data for relative bindings. Use NULL if hrow does not contain relative bindings.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.
Note
The cursor must have been previously prepared by a call to db_prepare_sql_cursor.

The query can contain placeholders of the form ":<type>fieldno", where type is the name of an SQL data type and fieldno is a number, starting from 0. The following query contains two placeholders:

select * from a where x = :<integer>0 and y = :<nvarchar>1

When the query is executed, the value for each placeholder is read from the corresponding field in param_row. After the cursor is executed, do not modify or free param_row until execution is ended by db_close_cursor or db_unexecute.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_EINVAL Caused by: invalid cursor.
  • DB_ESTATE Object state is not compatible with the method called or arguments. This could be caused by invalid transaction state.
  • DB_ESQLTABLENOTEXISTS A referenced table does not exist.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDCOLUMNNAME A referenced column does not exist.
  • DB_ESQLCOLUMNAMBIGUOUSLYDEFINED A referenced column is not specifically defined.
  • DB_ESQLINCOMPATIBLETYPES Incompatible types between two or more variables.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDFUNCTIONNAME Unrecognized function used in SQL statement.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDNUMBEROFARGUMENTS Invalid number of arguments used in SQL function call.
  • DB_ESQLININVALIDARGUMENTTYPE Invalid argument type used in SQL function call.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDQUALIFIER Invalid SQL qualifier used in SQL statement.
  • DB_ESQLINCOMPATIBLEROWTYPES Incompatible row types used in SQL statement.
  • DB_ESQLPARSEERROR SQL parsing error. Refer to SQL syntax documentation.
  • DB_ESQLNOTAGROUPBYEXPRESSION Invalid Group-By expression in SQL statement.
  • DB_ESQLFEATURENOTALLOWED Invalid feature reference.
  • DB_ESQLDIVIDEBYZERO SQL Statement results in divide-by-zero.
  • DB_ESQLINVALIDRELATIONALOPERATOR Invalid table relation specified.
  • DB_ESQLNOTSORTABLETYPE Sort specified for unsortable data type.
  • DB_ESQLCODESIZETOOLARGE SQL statement too complex to decipher.
  • DB_EINVALIDNUMBER Invalid number encountered during execution.
  • DB_ESQLROWSIZETOOLARGE Required row size too large for internal buffers.
  • DB_EINDVALUE Invalid length indicator (*ind_ptr) value in parameter row.
  • DB_ENULLFIELD Insert or update would violate a NOT NULL constraint. Use a value that is not null.

This function may alter the transaction state.

See also
db_close_cursor,
db_get_error_message, get_db_error, clear_db_error, Error Handling

◆ db_is_browsable()

int db_is_browsable ( db_cursor_t  hcursor)

Determine if cursor can be iterated to fetch data in rows with db_fetch.

SQL insert, update, and delete cursors are not browsable. Table cursors and SQL select cursors are browsable.

Parameters
hcursorAn cursor.
Returns
> 0 if cursor is browsable; 0 if not browsable; or -1 on error.
See also
db_fetch, db_seek_first, db_seek_next

◆ db_server_start()

db_result_t db_server_start ( const db_server_config_t *  config)

Start the embedded ITTIA DB IPC server.

A thread is created in this process to listen for connections. A thread is also created for each active connection.

Parameters
configServer configuration.

If the max_connections configuration option is not zero, the number of active connections is limited to max_connections. A thread pool may be created containing max_connections threads. If max_connections is zero, the number of connections is limited only by the number of threads that can be created by a process on the current platform.

Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_ENOTIMPL The embedded server is not implemented. Link with the ITTIA DB-SQL client/server library to access this feature.
  • DB_EIPCALREADYSTARTED The server is already running and cannot be started again.
See also
db_server_stop, db_server_connection_count, db_server_config_init

◆ db_server_stop()

db_result_t db_server_stop ( db_flags_t  flags)

Stop the embedded ITTIA DB IPC server.

All IPC clients are disconnected and incomplete client transactions are rolled back automatically. Any C API calls that are currently executing will usually finish normally before the client is disconnected.

db_server_stop returns only when the connection listener thread finishes, or immediately if the server is already stopped or stopping in another thread.

Parameters
flagsFlags are ignored. Reserved for future use. Always set flags to 0.
Returns
  • DB_OK when successful.
  • DB_FAIL on failure.

On failure, one of the following error codes is set:

  • DB_ENOTIMPL The embedded server is not implemented. Link with the ITTIA DB-SQL client/server library to access this feature.
See also
db_server_start, db_server_connection_count

◆ db_server_connection_count()

int32_t db_server_connection_count ( void  )

Count the number of active connections to the server.

Returns
The number of clients currently connected to the server, or -1 if the server is not running.

◆ db_api_statistics()

int db_api_statistics ( db_api_statistics_t *  stats,
int  flags 
)

Get C API resource statistics.

Parameters
statsDestination for statistics (may be NULL).
flagsOne of:
  • DB_STATISTICS_QUERY: Query statistics.
  • DB_STATISTICS_RESET: Reset max value statistics after they are read into stats.
  • DB_STATISTICS_ENABLE: Enable statistics collection.
  • DB_STATISTICS_DISABLE: Disable statistics collection.
Returns
  • 1 when statistics are enabled prior to calling this function.
  • 0 when statistics are disabled prior to calling this function.
  • -1 on failure.

◆ db_lm_statistics()

int db_lm_statistics ( db_lm_statistics_t *  stats,
int  flags 
)

Get lock manager statistics.

Parameters
statsDestination for statistics (may be NULL).
flagsOne of:
  • DB_STATISTICS_QUERY: Query statistics.
  • DB_STATISTICS_RESET: Reset max value statistics after they are read into stats.
  • DB_STATISTICS_ENABLE: Enable statistics collection.
  • DB_STATISTICS_DISABLE: Disable statistics collection.
Returns
  • 1 when statistics are enabled prior to calling this function.
  • 0 when statistics are disabled prior to calling this function.
  • DB_ENOTIMPL when the built-in allocator is not supported.

◆ db_mem_statistics()

int db_mem_statistics ( db_mem_statistics_t *  stats,
int  flags 
)

Get built-in memory allocator statistics.

Parameters
statsDestination for statistics.
flagsOne of:
  • DB_STATISTICS_QUERY: Query statistics.
  • DB_STATISTICS_RESET: Reset max value statistics. Combine with DB_STATISTICS_QUERY to reset after statistics are read.
Returns
  • 1 when statistics are enabled.
  • 0 when statistics are disabled.
  • DB_ESTATE when the built-in allocator is not enabled.
  • DB_ENOTIMPL when the built-in allocator is not supported.

To collect memory statistics, the built-in allocator must be enabled with the DB_MEMFLAGS_TRACE flag set. Also, only QA builds of the library are capable of collecting memory statistics due to the additional overhead it introduces.

Only memory allocations performed by ITTIA DB are counted.
